para.para.body: Which of the following are true?
Every hyperspace is also a hyperplane.
True
Correct! - A hyperspace is a hyperplane with a special property: It passes through the origin.
False
Sorry! No! – Please review the definition of hyperspace and hyperplane
Every hyperplane is also a hyperspace.
True
Sorry! No! – Please review the definition of hyperspace and hyperplane
False
Correct! – There are lots of hyperplanes which do not pass through the origin, and such hyperplanes are not hyperspaces.
A hyperspace is the same thing as a hyperplane.
True
Sorry! No! – Please review the definition of hyperspace and hyperplane
False
Correct! – There are lots of hyperplanes which do not pass through the origin, and such hyperplanes are not hyperspaces.
A hyperplane is a 2-dimensional hyperspace.
True
Sorry, no! – A hyperplane need not be two dimensional.
False
Correct! – A hyperplane need not be 2 -dimensional, nor need it pass through the origin (as a hyperspace must).

Amongst the points which lie on H we find the following by inspection.
(1,1,0) lies on H because 3\cdot 1 - 2\cdot 1 + 0=1 is true.
(0,-1/2,0) lies on H because 3\cdot 0 - 2\cdot (-1/2) + 0=1 is true.
(0,0,1) lies on H because 3\cdot 0 - 2\cdot 0 + 1=1 is true.
Amongst the points which do not lie on H we find the following by inspection.
(1,0,0) does not lie on H because 3\cdot 1 - 2\cdot 0 + 0=1 is false.
(0,1,0) does not lie on H because 3\cdot 0 - 2\cdot 1 + 0=1 is false.
(0,0,6) does not lie on H because 3\cdot 0 - 2\cdot 0 + 6=1 is false.

Look first for equations whose corresponding hyperplanes are parallel. Two hyperplanes are parallel if their normal vectors are parallel.
Amongst equations for parallel hyperplanes look for equations which describe the same hyperplane. The solutions of equations
form equal hyperplanes exactly when their equations are equivalent, that is when the vectors (a_1,\dots ,a_n,c) and (b_1,\dots ,b_n,d) are parallel.
To find pairs of equations whose corresponding hyperplanes are parallel, we look for pairs of equations with parallel normal vectors.
These normal vectors are
We see that the following vectors are parallel:
(I), (VI) and (VII)

Now we look for equations whose solutions form equal hyperplanes amongst (I), (VI) and (VII), and amongst (II), (III), (V), and (VIII).
We find that (VI) = (-1)\cdot (I) . So these two equations describe the same hyperplane, and this hyperplane is parallel, but distinct, from the one given by (VII).
We find that (V) = 2\cdot (II) . So these two equations describe the same hyperplane, and all the other hyperplanes in this collection are pairwise distinct.
